newsitem.title: CANADA: BC Tel seeks local phone service rate hike.
newsitem.headline: BC Tel seeks local phone service rate hike.

text.p: BC Telecom Inc said on Wednesday it asked the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission (CRTC) to approve an increase in the price it can charge for residential and some commercial local telephone service.
The increase for residential customers would range between C$0.15 and C$1.50 a month with an average increase of C$0.70. The basic single-line home service now costs C$16 a month.
Businesses with a single line would see changes in their local phone service cost ranging from a decrease of C$9.90 a month to an increase of C$4.25 a month.
The decreases would be mostly in larger communities.

BC Tel said it was asking for the rate changes to take effect January 1 at the same time as a C$2 a month increase announced last year. That increase is the second of three annual increases announced by the CRTC for all Canadian telephone companies. BC Tel said it ran a deficit of C$450 million for basic residential phone service in 1995.

It costs the company about C$30 a month, or nearly twice the average price charged, to provide the service. The company said it expects the price of basic single-line residential service to rise to between C$25 and C$30 a month by 2000.
